threat: Unauthorized Access to Vehicle Design Data
threat_description: Unauthorized access to proprietary vehicle designs poses a major risk in the automotive industry. Attackers may infiltrate design networks or steal sensitive blueprints through cyber espionage, leading to intellectual property theft. Such breaches can result in financial losses, competitive disadvantages, and unauthorized replication of technology by foreign entities or rival companies. Weak access controls and insufficient encryption exacerbate these risks.

motives.motive: Financial Gain through Intellectual Property Theft

components.name: Design and Engineering Systems
components.description: Secure networks, software platforms, and databases used for designing, testing, and storing proprietary vehicle blueprints.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-521: Weak Password Requirements
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Weak password policies in Automotive Design and Engineering Systems enable cyber adversaries to brute-force or steal credentials, granting unauthorized access to proprietary vehicle blueprints and critical intellectual property.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Poorly secured access controls result in the inadvertent exposure of proprietary vehicle designs to unauthorized actors, allowing competitors or foreign entities to acquire confidential automotive engineering details.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-287: Improper Authentication
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Improper authentication mechanisms in design platforms enable attackers to bypass security controls, gaining unauthorized access to vehicle prototypes and intellectual property repositories.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-284: Improper Access Control
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Insufficient access control measures allow unauthorized actors to infiltrate Automotive Design and Engineering Systems, potentially extracting or modifying sensitive vehicle design data, leading to intellectual property theft.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-639: Authorization Bypass Through User-Controlled Key
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Weak authorization mechanisms allow adversaries to manipulate access tokens and gain unauthorized control over proprietary vehicle design files, leading to intellectual property theft and unauthorized modifications.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-863: Incorrect Authorization
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Flawed authorization policies allow unauthorized personnel or external actors to access and alter vehicle design files, leading to intellectual property theft or compromised product development processes.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Automotive design blueprints and proprietary engineering data stored or transmitted without encryption can be intercepted by attackers, leading to unauthorized replication of technology and competitive disadvantage.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: A lack of comprehensive logging within Automotive Design and Engineering Systems hinders early detection of unauthorized access, allowing cyber adversaries to exfiltrate sensitive vehicle design data without triggering alerts.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-502: Deserialization of Untrusted Data
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Automotive Design Systems that improperly deserialize user-supplied data are vulnerable to code injection, allowing attackers to manipulate or destroy sensitive vehicle design information.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-918: Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF)
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: SSRF vulnerabilities allow attackers to trick internal servers into making unauthorized requests, potentially exposing proprietary automotive design files to external adversaries.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Improper input validation within design management interfaces could allow attackers to inject malicious data, potentially corrupting or altering critical vehicle design files and causing long-term production issues.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-94: Improper Control of Generation of Code (Code Injection)
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Attackers could exploit weak security mechanisms to inject unauthorized code into engineering software, modifying or corrupting proprietary vehicle design data, leading to compromised product integrity.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-434: Unrestricted Upload of File with Dangerous Type
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Malicious actors could exploit weak file validation in Automotive Design Systems to upload unauthorized files, potentially compromising the integrity of proprietary vehicle blueprints and engineering data.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Failure to implement encrypted transmission protocols in Automotive Design and Engineering Systems exposes vehicle design blueprints to interception, facilitating cyber espionage and unauthorized replication of proprietary technology.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-601: URL Redirection to Untrusted Site (Open Redirect)
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Cyber adversaries could leverage URL redirection vulnerabilities within engineering portals to redirect employees to phishing sites, compromising design credentials and enabling unauthorized access to proprietary vehicle data.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-89: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an SQL Command (SQL Injection)
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: SQL Injection vulnerabilities within Automotive Design and Engineering databases could allow attackers to manipulate database queries, resulting in unauthorized access, theft, or destruction of proprietary vehicle design data.

threat: Compromise of Engineering and Simulation Systems
threat_description: Automotive design and testing rely on advanced engineering and simulation tools. If compromised, attackers could manipulate vehicle performance data, introduce design flaws, or delay production. Threat actors may exploit vulnerabilities in these systems to alter key safety or efficiency parameters, potentially leading to regulatory compliance issues or hazardous product defects.

motives.motive: Disruption of Automotive Manufacturing and Safety Standards

components.name: Engineering and Simulation Platforms
components.description: Specialized software and digital tools used for designing, testing, and simulating vehicle performance, safety, and efficiency.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-521: Weak Password Requirements
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Weak password policies in Engineering and Simulation Platforms enable attackers to brute-force or steal credentials, granting unauthorized access to proprietary vehicle performance models and design simulation tools. This can lead to tampering with critical test data or unauthorized modifications of engineering parameters.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Poorly secured access controls result in the inadvertent exposure of confidential vehicle simulation data to unauthorized actors, allowing competitors or foreign entities to acquire proprietary testing methodologies.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-287: Improper Authentication
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Improper authentication mechanisms in Engineering and Simulation Platforms enable attackers to bypass security controls, gaining unauthorized access to confidential vehicle performance data and safety test models.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-284: Improper Access Control
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Insufficient access control measures allow unauthorized actors to infiltrate Engineering and Simulation Platforms, potentially altering key vehicle safety parameters or manipulating efficiency testing data. Such breaches could compromise regulatory compliance and introduce safety-critical flaws.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-639: Authorization Bypass Through User-Controlled Key
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Weak authorization mechanisms allow adversaries to manipulate access tokens and gain unauthorized control over vehicle test parameters, leading to incorrect performance assessments or manipulated regulatory compliance reports.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-863: Incorrect Authorization
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Flawed authorization policies allow unauthorized personnel or external actors to modify simulation parameters, potentially leading to inaccurate vehicle test results and compromised regulatory compliance.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Proprietary simulation models and engineering data stored or transmitted without encryption can be intercepted by attackers, leading to unauthorized access, replication of critical test parameters, or manipulation of vehicle design specifications.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-89: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an SQL Command (SQL Injection)
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: SQL Injection vulnerabilities within Engineering and Simulation Platforms could allow attackers to manipulate database queries, resulting in unauthorized access, modification, or deletion of proprietary vehicle design and test results.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: A lack of comprehensive logging within Engineering and Simulation Platforms prevents early detection of unauthorized access, allowing attackers to stealthily manipulate or exfiltrate sensitive vehicle simulation data without triggering alerts.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-502: Deserialization of Untrusted Data
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Engineering and Simulation Platforms that improperly deserialize user-supplied data are vulnerable to malicious code injection, allowing attackers to manipulate or destroy sensitive vehicle performance data.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-918: Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF)
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: SSRF vulnerabilities allow attackers to manipulate internal server requests, potentially exposing proprietary engineering models and simulated vehicle performance data to external adversaries.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Improper input validation within simulation software interfaces could allow attackers to inject malicious data, potentially corrupting vehicle performance models and leading to inaccurate safety or efficiency assessments.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-94: Improper Control of Generation of Code (Code Injection)
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Attackers could exploit weak security mechanisms to inject unauthorized code into engineering software, modifying or corrupting simulation results and introducing flawed vehicle performance predictions, potentially leading to unsafe designs.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-434: Unrestricted Upload of File with Dangerous Type
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Malicious actors could exploit weak file validation in Engineering and Simulation Platforms to upload unauthorized files, potentially corrupting critical simulation environments and affecting vehicle safety analysis.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-601: URL Redirection to Untrusted Site (Open Redirect)
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Cyber adversaries could leverage URL redirection vulnerabilities within simulation platforms to redirect engineers to phishing sites, compromising credentials and enabling unauthorized access to proprietary vehicle simulation data.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Failure to implement encrypted transmission protocols in Engineering and Simulation Platforms exposes vehicle test results to interception, enabling attackers to manipulate or steal proprietary safety and efficiency data.

threat_description: Automotive companies collaborate with third-party suppliers for design and prototyping. Cybercriminals may target these suppliers, leveraging weak security measures to steal sensitive design information. Stolen intellectual property could be used for counterfeiting, undermining competitive advantage, and impacting global market positioning.

motives.motive: Financial Gain through Intellectual Property Theft

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-89: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an SQL Command (SQL Injection)

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: A lack of comprehensive logging within Supply Chain Management and Vendor Systems prevents early detection of unauthorized access, allowing attackers to exfiltrate or manipulate automotive design data without triggering security alerts. cwes.cwe_id: CWE-502: Deserialization of Untrusted Data

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-918: Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF)

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-94: Improper Control of Generation of Code (Code Injection)

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-434: Unrestricted Upload of File with Dangerous Type
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Malicious actors could exploit weak file validation in Supply Chain Management and Vendor Systems to upload unauthorized files, potentially introducing malware, disrupting manufacturing processes, or compromising sensitive automotive supplier data.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-601: URL Redirection to Untrusted Site (Open Redirect)

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Failure to implement encrypted transmission protocols in Supply Chain Management and Vendor Systems exposes automotive design files and supplier contracts to interception, enabling cyber espionage and unauthorized data leakage.

threat_description: Sensitive R&D data, including vehicle designs and emerging technologies, is at risk of unauthorized access or leaks. Weak access controls, insecure data-sharing, and third-party vulnerabilities can lead to exposure, resulting in financial loss, competitive disadvantages, and regulatory issues.

components.name: Research & Development Networks and Data Repositories
components.description: Secure environments, cloud storage, and digital collaboration tools used to store and manage proprietary automotive R&D data.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-521: Weak Password Requirements
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Weak password policies in Research & Development Networks and Data Repositories allow attackers to brute-force or steal credentials, granting unauthorized access to proprietary vehicle designs and emerging technologies. This enables industrial spies to extract R&D data, accelerating their own technological advancements while bypassing costly research investments.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Poorly secured access policies in R&D platforms may inadvertently expose confidential vehicle development data to unauthorized actors. This enables competitors or state-backed entities to acquire advanced automotive research insights and accelerate their own innovation cycles.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-287: Improper Authentication
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Weak authentication mechanisms in R&D data storage systems enable attackers to bypass login security, gaining direct access to confidential engineering research and leveraging stolen insights to enhance their own technological developments.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-284: Improper Access Control
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Lack of stringent access control mechanisms in R&D systems enables unauthorized users to infiltrate proprietary design repositories, stealing confidential engineering data. This allows competitors or state-sponsored entities to exploit stolen insights and improve their own vehicle designs.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-639: Authorization Bypass Through User-Controlled Key
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Weak session management in R&D data systems allows attackers to manipulate access tokens, gaining unauthorized control over proprietary vehicle designs. This enables the theft of confidential engineering breakthroughs for unauthorized replication.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-863: Incorrect Authorization
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Flawed authorization mechanisms permit unauthorized users to access restricted R&D files, leading to the theft of confidential automotive blueprints and technical documentation, accelerating the attackerâ€™s own vehicle innovation process.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Failure to encrypt sensitive vehicle design data in Research & Development repositories leaves it vulnerable to interception. Attackers can exfiltrate unprotected design schematics and research findings, gaining a technological advantage without investing in extensive R&D.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-89: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an SQL Command (SQL Injection)
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: SQL Injection vulnerabilities within R&D databases could allow attackers to manipulate database queries, resulting in unauthorized access, extraction, or modification of proprietary vehicle development information.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Insufficient logging within R&D data storage systems prevents the timely detection of unauthorized access. Attackers can exfiltrate proprietary designs and advanced research details over an extended period, accelerating their own automotive innovations without being detected.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-502: Deserialization of Untrusted Data
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Research and development platforms that improperly deserialize external data inputs are vulnerable to code injection, allowing attackers to manipulate or destroy proprietary vehicle research findings and siphon critical innovation data.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-918: Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF)
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: SSRF vulnerabilities allow attackers to manipulate internal network requests, potentially exposing proprietary research and development files to external adversaries who seek to gain an automotive innovation advantage.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Weak input validation in R&D collaboration platforms allows attackers to inject malicious payloads, corrupting simulation models and manipulating design parameters. This could result in compromised vehicle safety features and stolen design improvements.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-94: Improper Control of Generation of Code (Code Injection)
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Attackers could exploit vulnerabilities in R&D engineering software to inject malicious scripts, modifying proprietary design files and allowing competitors to introduce hidden weaknesses or extract valuable research data.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-434: Unrestricted Upload of File with Dangerous Type
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Malicious actors could exploit insecure file upload mechanisms in R&D portals to introduce unauthorized files, embedding malware for long-term access or corrupting critical research data to disrupt development cycles.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-601: URL Redirection to Untrusted Site (Open Redirect)
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Attackers could exploit open redirection vulnerabilities in R&D portals to redirect engineers to phishing sites, stealing credentials and enabling unauthorized access to confidential design schematics and prototype data.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Transmitting sensitive automotive R&D data in cleartext across unsecured networks exposes it to interception by adversaries. This allows industrial spies to steal proprietary technology blueprints, fast-tracking their own vehicle development without detection.

threat_description: Cyberattacks targeting manufacturing plants can halt production lines, causing substantial financial losses. Attackers may use ransomware, malware, or denial-of-service (DoS) attacks to disable automated assembly operations, disrupting vehicle manufacturing on a large scale.

threat_description: Malicious actors may exploit weaknesses in firmware updates or embedded vehicle systems, injecting unauthorized code. This could lead to functional defects, cybersecurity vulnerabilities in mass-produced vehicles, or even unauthorized remote control of certain car functions.

threat: Unauthorized Manipulation of Vehicle Diagnostic and Tuning Systems
threat_description: Automotive repair shops rely on diagnostic tools to assess vehicle performance. If these systems are compromised, incorrect readings could be injected, leading to unnecessary repairs, incorrect part replacements, or compromised vehicle safety.

components.name: Vehicle Diagnostic and Tuning Systems
components.description: Electronic tools and software platforms used by automotive repair shops to assess vehicle performance, detect faults, and apply tuning modifications.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-521: Weak Password Requirements
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Weak password policies in vehicle diagnostic systems allow attackers to gain unauthorized access, manipulating diagnostic outputs and leading to unnecessary repairs or incorrect part replacements.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Exposure of vehicle diagnostic data due to weak authentication measures enables attackers to analyze vehicle performance information, identifying vulnerabilities for exploitation.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-287: Improper Authentication
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Weak authentication mechanisms in vehicle diagnostic tools allow attackers to bypass login security, gaining unauthorized access to vehicle calibration and error code settings.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-284: Improper Access Control
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Improper access control mechanisms in diagnostic tools allow attackers to escalate privileges, modifying vehicle performance data and introducing safety risks.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-639: Authorization Bypass Through User-Controlled Key
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Authorization bypass vulnerabilities in vehicle tuning software allow adversaries to manipulate calibration settings, potentially altering vehicle safety mechanisms.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-863: Incorrect Authorization
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Flawed authorization mechanisms allow unauthorized modifications to vehicle diagnostic records, leading to unsafe tuning settings and performance manipulations.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Lack of encryption in diagnostic data storage and transmissions exposes vehicle diagnostics to interception, allowing attackers to alter performance readings or inject false errors.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Insufficient logging in vehicle diagnostic platforms prevents early detection of unauthorized data manipulations, allowing prolonged tampering with diagnostic results.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-502: Deserialization of Untrusted Data
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Deserialization vulnerabilities in diagnostic software enable attackers to inject manipulated data, potentially corrupting vehicle tuning parameters or diagnostic logs.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-918: Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF)
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: SSRF vulnerabilities in diagnostic tuning platforms allow attackers to manipulate internal requests, potentially exposing sensitive vehicle performance data and calibration settings.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Weak input validation in vehicle diagnostic interfaces allows attackers to inject malicious data, potentially altering error codes or falsifying maintenance alerts.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-94: Improper Control of Generation of Code (Code Injection)
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Code injection vulnerabilities in diagnostic tuning software allow attackers to introduce malicious scripts, compromising vehicle performance and introducing potential safety hazards.

cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Unrestricted file upload vulnerabilities in vehicle diagnostic systems allow attackers to introduce malware, compromising system integrity and enabling unauthorized remote access.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Cleartext transmission of diagnostic data in automotive tuning platforms exposes performance and fault records to interception by cybercriminals.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-601: URL Redirection to Untrusted Site (Open Redirect)
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Open redirect vulnerabilities in vehicle diagnostic platforms could allow attackers to redirect mechanics or technicians to phishing sites, stealing credentials and enabling unauthorized access to vehicle systems.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-89: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an SQL Command (SQL Injection)
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: SQL Injection vulnerabilities in diagnostic and tuning databases allow attackers to manipulate or extract sensitive vehicle performance records, compromising vehicle maintenance data.

threat: Abuse of Remote Vehicle Maintenance and OTA (Over-The-Air) Update Services
threat_description: Many modern vehicles offer remote diagnostics and over-the-air updates. Attackers exploiting these services could manipulate vehicle settings, disable key safety functions, or install malicious software updates, affecting vehicle integrity.

motives.motive: Disruption of Vehicle Operations and Safety

threat: Unauthorized Access to Vehicle Diagnostic and Service Data
threat_description: Automotive repair and customization platforms store sensitive vehicle diagnostics, service history, and proprietary tuning data. Weak access controls, improper privilege management, or insecure APIs can lead to unauthorized access, risking data leaks, unauthorized modifications, or exploitation of vehicle systems.

motives.motive: Technological Advantage through Theft of Proprietary Data
